Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2008 11:11PM LynnInCalif wrote: A 2nd opinion is routine with this disease.  Try to go to a major university or a renowned breast cancer center, take your films, pathology reports, a letter from your surgeon with his recommendations (he shouldn't mind unless he has an inferiority complex; this is your wife's life we are talking about, as you know).  They make appts rapidly at this places, I have found.  They realize the urgency.  John Hopkins is great.  Their website is as well, www.johnhopkins.com where a woman by the name of Lillie helps to guide you through this process. She is a 2 time BC survivor and the head of the department there.  She, in fact, is a featured expert on this site as well. Gather information from multiple sources and then make your decision.  God speed.
Posts.Title: Husband of "Just Diagnosed" meinny7 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 11:58PM LynnInCalif wrote: I am so glad to hear this, Stephanie.  It is so important that your life be as enjoyable as it can be and having an appetite for food (yum!) and feeling less discomfort will help to ensure that.  My heart is with you on this path we are on.  Bless your heart for being so courageous.  You give me strength.
Posts.Title: I got my brownies! TripleNeg AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 12:01AM - edited Dec 16, 2008 12:08AM by LynnInCalif Instructions: Brown the finely chopped marijuana in a pan with a little oil. Do not crisp or burn it, just slightly brown it. Mix dry ingredients in a bowl. Mix wet ingredients in a separate bowl. Pour wet into dry and beat until smooth. Pour into greased muffin tin, or you can use cupcake papers. Bake at 350oC for 20 minutes. Top with icing and serve.   http://www.onlinepot.org/recipes.htm#Alice%20B.%20Tokla's%20Brownies  This website is for the young folks (be prepared for it), scroll down to the bottom for recipes galore.

Posts.Title: Morphine all day everyday - Things are getting serious TripleNeg lewisfamily503

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 01:13AM LynnInCalif wrote: I also was Rx'ed Provigil by my oncologist.  My fatigue was affecting my job performance.  He surprisingly did not ask any questions and gave me Rx.  Expensive med, $278/month.   I had some old diet pills (Fastin) in the cabinet and actually tried those.  It is not possible for me to be in a state of inertia; I am a one-woman show.  Though, still, I am in pajamas all day and shamefully admit that I could sleep all day if allowed.  Two cups of double espresso latte doesn't even phase me.
Posts.Title: Endless FATIGUE......Anyone?? Krissy37 Krissy37

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2008 11:49PM LynnInCalif wrote: I sought a pharmaceutical when I literally slept in for work several days in a row.   And I didn't do chemo.  This fatigue had to go as it was interfering with my life; I needed things done and no one but me could do them.  Namely, work but also clean the house, maintain car, yard, yada yada yada, I even managed to forget to pay the water bill for 3 months.  Too darn tired to even think about that mundane everyday stuff.  Let me watch a movie, please...Alas, not an option.  So bring on the drugs. Provigil which is keeping my brain from that sleepy drowsy feeling and the great part is I don't feel drugged.  I also take Prozac with it.  High BP is a contraindication.  It is Rx'ed to MS patients, night shift workers and those with sleep apnea or sleeping disorders.  Very expensive, did i mention that?  about 230 for a month's supply.   Am even knocking off a few lbs as I am moving around the house more.   This is a CNS stimulant.  Food is still appealing and there is no dry mouth like diet pills of the past.  I agree it is due to lack of estrogen.  After Femara for just a month, it occurred to me that really old folks move slow in part because they don't have energy to move any faster than that.  That is something to look forward to ::gulp::
Posts.Title: Still have the fatigue after 2 years. Mary-Lou Molly2013

Posts.Content: LynnInCalif wrote: Post-radiation syndrome as a NO/ONOO(-) cycle, chronic fatigue syndrome-like disease - Source: Medical Hypotheses, Jul 29, 2008 by Martin L. Pall, PhD ImmuneSupport.com 08-04-2008 Advertisement [Note: for information on the NO/ONOO(-) cycle, see "Nitric Oxide Cycle Theory: Will It Explain CFS, FM, and Other ‘Unexplained' Illnesses? - Q&A with Martin L. Pall, PhD". Dr. Pall is author of the groundbreaking book, Explaining Unexplained Illnesses] Post-radiation syndrome is proposed to be chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) or a chronic fatigue syndrome-like illness, initiated by exposure to ionizing radiation. This view is supported by the nitric oxide/peroxynitrite (NO/ONOO(-)) cycle mechanism, the putative etiologic mechanism for CFS and related illnesses. Ionizing radiation may initiate illness by increasing nitric oxide levels via increased activity of the transcription factor NF-kappaB and consequent increased synthesis of the inducible nitric oxide synthase. [Some sources of ionizing radiation include X-rays, gamma rays, radon, atomic weapons test fallout. Types of radiant energy that are not ionizing include microwaves, radio waves, UV light and visible light, according to the World Health Organization.] Two types of components of the nitric oxide/peroxynitrite cycle have been studied in post-radiation syndrome patients and shown to be elevated. The symptoms and signs of post-radiation syndrome and its chronicity are similar or identical to those of chronic fatigue syndrome and can be explained as being a consequence of nitric oxide/peroxynitrite cycle etiology. While the data available to test this view are limited, it provides for the first time a comprehensive explanation for post-radiation syndrome. Source: Medical Hypotheses, July 29, 2008. [E-pub ahead of print] PMID: 18667279, by Pall ML. School of Molecular Biosciences, Washington State University, Pullman, Washington, USA. [E-mail: martin_pall@wsu.edu] Dx 3/28/2007, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2008 02:03AM LynnInCalif wrote: Danielle, can you ask your mom to look on her path report to see if her cancer was estrogen/progesterone positive?  her2neu also is tested and that result is important.  I think that I would get a second opinion, if I were your mom.  If she is menopausal, there is debate regarding chemo being issued to node neg patients who are ER/PR positive.  Tell her to get an appt hopefully at a breast cancer specialty center or medical center, if you have to, drive miles and spend night in motel (which is what I did).   I am sorry she has to go through this life altering ordeal at a time in her life when this is the last thing that she should be doing.  She is a lucky woman to have a daughter such as yourself.  You are a brave girl.
